after many wipes, there is only one thing i can tell you about rust - it is horrid for anyone with small amounts of time on their hands.

if you decide to play every day for 1-2 hours per day on a purely vanilla server; it is not enough to maintain with the growth of the rest of the players who do have the countless hours on their hands to play and progress. you will be raided, and you will die often.

if you are a solo; you will be wiped off the face of this earth by clans and zergs.

however, its important to look away from just vanilla, and begin mentioning different rules and modes:

this game has such a wide range of mods and modes that accustom to the type of player you are. this makes up for the terrible community and playstyle of vanilla rust.

in conclusion, the concept of rust is great. the community has its pros and cons.

Actually the biggest fall off of 2024, the game has been absolutely trashed. The developers do not give a shit and only put effort into things that make them money, not by game quality but by in game micro-transactions that do absolutely nothing to improve the player experience unless that player is bound by pay to win logic rather than expanded content. All that aside, even if it were not an issue it can be easily be overshadowed by the fact that the player base is notoriously the worst in gaming history rivaling that of any game you can think of. There is copious amounts of racism, homophobia, and psychological assault in the form of expressing to others that they should end their own lives from the players. Do yourself a favor and do not purchase this game. If you watch Rust on YouTube and expect it to be as presented you are in for the rudest awakening imaginable, play anything else and buy anything else with your money do not feed these monetarily driven developers and suffering driven player base. If you think that old Rust was good you could make a better argument but its never going back to that and we all know it.

Played solo. Game performance is horrible. Takes forever to load. Crashes and lags horribly. No smooth game play. I play CoD on high settings, no problem. There's a million servers but no clue which one is suitable for me. Game mechanics are weird. I got shot by a sentry in a safe zone. When you log off in the wrong place (like the outpost safe zone) you literally loose everything you carry. So if you don't have a base you can and probably will be killed when you logoff. Even if you have a base you probably get raided offline anyway. Your base has an upkeep and decays if you don't have enough materials in storage, so if you have a life and don't want to spend all your game time gathering materials for your base's upkeep you have to stick with the smallest possible base. Sorry for those who like base building and pvp at the same time. Most servers wipe weekly or monthly anyway so why bother anyway. I regret paying for this game.

Once upon a time in the brutal landscape of Rust, there lived a hapless soul who found themselves in a never-ending cycle of chaos and absurdity.

Our protagonist, let's call them Rusty, ventured forth into the wilderness armed with nothing but a rock and a sliver of hope. But alas, hope was a fleeting companion in this unforgiving realm.

As Rusty toiled away, gathering resources to build a modest shelter, they soon found themselves in the crosshairs of a merciless clan. Like a pack of rabid wolves, the clan descended upon Rusty with ruthless efficiency, leaving them bruised, battered, and contemplating the cruel twist of fate that had led them to this point.

But the trials were far from over. In a stroke of misfortune, Rusty woke up to find themselves shackled in chains, enslaved by a fellow survivor with delusions of grandeur. Forced to toil endlessly, Rusty became little more than a cog in the machine of their captor's ambitions, their dreams of freedom fading with each passing day.

And just when Rusty thought they had seen it all, they found themselves being pursued by a horde of naked, shrieking children armed with little more than crude weaponry and boundless energy. It was a scene straight out of a fever dream, with Rusty running for dear life as insults and threats rained down upon them like a torrential downpour.

In the end, Rusty learned a valuable lesson: in the world of Rust, survival was not just about outwitting the elements, but also navigating the treacherous waters of human nature. And as they continued their journey through this savage landscape, they did so with a newfound sense of caution, ever wary of the dangers that lurked around every corner.

Good MMO survival game!
8/10

+ Good graphics and visual effects.
+ Good sound effects.
± Hardcore gameplay.
+ High replayability.
+ Full freedom of action.
+ Destructible game environment.
+ Lots of PvP.
+ Lots of PvE.
+ Lots of PvP during PvE events.
+ Building houses, settlements, fortresses.
+ Lots of crafts.
+ Lots of research.

- Lots of grind.
- Sometimes there are cheaters.
- Impossible to create and change a character (even gender).
- Server wipes (weekly, biweekly, monthly).

The game is not for casual solo players, because hardcore players will f*ck you at every turn!
Fun to play, especially with friends!

This, out of all my hours in gaming, was the one game to let me know that I was TOO OLD to be competitive. I just don't have the time others do anymore so I'm playing a base building/farming/waiting to do it all over again simulator. Rust rewards time played, AS IT SHOULD, but I find it unplayable if I don't have time to keep up with others who do. The curve is HUGE between having a couple hours or spending all day. You put the time in, you deserve the benefits 100000 percent, but I should be able to at least play the game lol. If I don't have the time, I don't even launch Rust. I'll make a trash stone base and log in the next day to a large wooden sign LMAO. (Before I get hate, yes, I know I can play PvE, I do often with my daughter, but sometimes, I wanna PvP ya know? I'm fast with good reactions, I just don't have the AK or Bolty, I got a bow. And I ain't no Willjum lol). I'm also aware skill plays a role in this and if I don't play enough, I won't get better with said bow, but I find getting started to just be so difficult sometimes. If I'm not logged in on a Thursday, I might as well just not play for a couple weeks. Just how I feel.

Balance in all things, hard to obtain. I'm not whining or saying GAME IS TOO HARD, just sayin'. I'm too old for this s*** and I assume others are too. FEELSBADMAN. OLD GAMERS UNITE!

Rust is a good game and if you have time, give it your time. It's fun, exciting and easily worth the money. Just know you NEED TIME to make it worth it. It's stressful and without the time needed, it's totally unnecessary stress. As I said, I'm old, I can't be getting stressed out for no reason anymore. I will perish. lmao

Overall I would recommend. It's the best format for an online game out there.

Pros: It's not a lame AI who you have to defeat, it is other people. Truly challenging. it will make you feel emotions like no other game can. The devs have added thousands of tid bits that are constantly found. If you watch 100 hours of video you will still be learning new things about the game. 

Cons: Rust is the home of the sweatiest of tryhards and cheaters. There are no casual rust players. There are extreme problems with server wipes. The state of the game only caters to people who will spend 12 hrs a day at the beginning of a server wipe. Then the servers die 2 days later. Newspawns, and especially new players, are extremely punished because the progression allows veterans to be playing end game content in 20 minutes that would take new players 5 days.

What the game needs: 
-Actual systems that ban cheaters. It's broken. Admins and servers ban people guessing if they cheat or not, or if they were around cheaters or not. You get banned if you have a VPN.
-STOP THE SERVER WIPE NONSENSE. Servers only last 2 days because its out of control. Find systems that make it worth playing a server longer.

EG
-Work bench recipe reworks. Make the work benches have a smoother progression. 
-progression restrictions. day 1 of wipe, only tier one workbenchs are craftable. Day 2 tier 2, Day 3 tier 3 [or something like that]. Something to smooth out the extreme imbalances.
-Make weapons progress better. 


Ultimately worth, but I can't wait until a AAA studio makes a better version of this .

Just recently i had stayed up from 4PM to 9 IN THE MORNING me and my friend just never reached a stopping point, he wanted to keep going but i was actually starting to feel ill, the fun of the game was being outweighed by my suffering from playing for so long.
never in my life have i ever played a single game until the sun came out. once i finally gave up i felt so horrible, i felt sick to my stomach and i felt weak. this game hurts you more than just "loosing loot". you loose your time, your health, and your sanity playing this game.
you HAVE to stay up to farm for your base, you HAVE to stay up to make sure no one is raiding you and god forbid you click the "Quit" button its all gone, that night you just spent slaving away at this game? all gone because you have been offlined, YAY!!!. for anyone looking to get into this game, dont, just stick to watching youtubers play it or something. this game is not worth your time and it sure as hell shouldn't be this fucking grindy.

If you REALLY want to play this game, please for the love of god limit yourself, once you start getting too deep into this game it reels you in and keeps you there for as long as it possibly can.

This game is fun, its very well made, but the gameplay loop needs a serious change. the time it takes to get things needs to be cut in HALF because even on 2x servers a casualish player like me takes about 2 days to get to ak, you could say this is a skill issue, and you may be right, but i dont want to spend sleepless nights grinding sulfur and metal and stone to keep my base up, its painful.

TL:DR, This game is too grindy for its own good, i don't recommend it because it can seriously damage your health.

9500 hours. I've played this stupid game for 9500 hours. Why? It's the best game. 

Like to craft? Rust. Like to explore? Rust. Like shooters? Rust. Want endless variance? Rust. Want thrilling victories and gut churning losses? Rust. Want to build your dream castle and live in it? Rust. Want to cover said dream castle in doom machines and profit from your deadly creation? Oh, right this way sir. 

No, there isn't a plot. No, your base and loot won't last forever. 

No you can't beat Rust, but you can certainly win.

From the moment I started playing Rust, I was completely hooked. The challenge and progression that comes with Rust is second to none. Once you know what you're doing, the game becomes a complete blast, and you have so much more fun. Adding some friends to the game completely changes the experience and elevates the game to a whole new level. The community is generally good, but like in all games, there are a few bad players that try to ruin your experience. Thankfully, nothing some satchels and an AK can't fix. There's always something to do in the game, and the constant updates keep the game balanced and fair, making it one of the best games out there.

Title: Rust: Crafting a Savage World of Survival

Introduction:
Rust, developed by Facepunch Studios, stands as an unparalleled testament to the survival genre in the realm of gaming. Released in early access in 2013 and officially launched in 2018, Rust has continuously evolved, setting new benchmarks for emergent gameplay, player interaction, and sheer intensity. As a veteran survivor of its virtual world, I am compelled to delve into the depths of Rust's unparalleled brilliance and its profound impact on the gaming landscape.

Graphics and Atmosphere:
Rust's visual fidelity is a double-edged sword, striking a balance between stark realism and raw beauty. The desolate landscapes, weather effects, and intricate environmental details immerse players in a world ravaged by decay and primal forces. From serene sunsets casting long shadows across rugged terrain to the ominous thunderstorms heralding imminent danger, Rust's atmospheric prowess transcends mere aesthetics, instilling a sense of awe and trepidation with every step.

Gameplay Mechanics:
At its core, Rust epitomizes the essence of survival, demanding unwavering resilience and cunning adaptability from its players. The game thrusts you into a merciless wilderness teeming with hostile wildlife, ruthless bandits, and the ever-looming specter of starvation and exposure. Yet, amidst the chaos, lies an intricate web of crafting, base building, and territorial warfare, where every decision carries weight and consequence.

The crafting system in Rust is a masterclass in complexity and depth, offering a staggering array of tools, weapons, and structures to scavenge, construct, and defend. From rudimentary stone hatchets to high-caliber firearms, the progression feels organic and gratifying, rewarding resourcefulness and innovation in equal measure.

Base building, another cornerstone of Rust's gameplay, transcends mere fortification, evolving into a strategic endeavor of architectural ingenuity and defensive prowess. The modular construction system allows players to design sprawling citadels or inconspicuous hideaways, each with its own vulnerabilities and strengths. The thrill of fortifying your stronghold against marauding raiders or orchestrating a covert infiltration of enemy territory is unparalleled, fostering a dynamic ecosystem of alliances, betrayals, and territorial conquest.

Community and Player Interaction:
One of Rust's most defining features lies in its unscripted, player-driven narratives that unfold within its vast sandbox world. The game's online multiplayer environment fosters a rich tapestry of alliances, rivalries, and emergent storytelling, where every encounter is a potential turning point in your journey.

The community dynamics in Rust are as unpredictable as they are compelling, ranging from tense negotiations and diplomatic overtures to ruthless betrayal and merciless vendettas. Whether forging alliances with fellow survivors to fend off common threats or waging relentless guerrilla warfare against rival factions, the social fabric of Rust's world is a testament to the boundless creativity and agency afforded to its players.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Rust stands as a towering monument to the indomitable spirit of human survival and ingenuity. Its immersive world, intricate gameplay mechanics, and vibrant community have solidified its status as a timeless classic in the annals of gaming history. As I traverse the desolate landscapes and forge alliances in the crucible of adversity, I am reminded of Rust's enduring legacy—a testament to the enduring power of human resilience and the unbridled potential of emergent gameplay. In a world defined by chaos and uncertainty, Rust remains a beacon of hope, offering solace and camaraderie amidst the ruins of civilization.

Dota 2 is a game that will challenge you, reward you, and keep you hooked for hours. It is a team-based multiplayer game where you can choose from over a hundred unique heroes, each with their own abilities and playstyles. You can cooperate with your allies, strategize against your enemies, and fight for objectives in three-lane maps. Dota 2 is constantly evolving with regular updates, new features, and fresh content. Whether you are a beginner or a veteran, there is always something new to discover and learn in Dota 2.

If you are looking for a game that offers deep and complex team strategy, generous and fair free-to-play model, and a vibrant and passionate community, then Dota 2 is the game for you. You can download it for free on Steam and join millions of players worldwide in the ultimate battle arena. Dota 2 is not just a game, it is a way of life.

16 million copies sold to less than 400k unique users.... what that means is more than 90% of the money face punch has made came directly from banned cheaters buying new accounts... this is reality for all shooting games now... when there is that much money to be made the developers will capitolize on it.... that part is a fact..... the conspiracy part is im pretty fuckin sure they make the cheats for their own games and just sell em via shell companies.... this makes good sense if your goal is to make the most money possible on your game... essentialy you are turning a 20$ play forever game into a monthly subscription to have an unfair advantage and many of these cheaters are dumping 100$ a month easy.... and im not realy bagging on facepunch for this practice... if i was making games i would do it too.... the fault for this practice lies with you the consumers..... they need ppl who dont cheat to be prey for the ppl who do to make this work....

I must say, Rust is, without a doubt, the epitome of a poorly designed, infuriating video game. From the moment I launched the game, my experience was a downward spiral into a virtual wasteland of frustration and disappointment. Allow me to vent my righteous anger and present to you the myriad reasons why Rust deserves nothing but contempt.

First and foremost, the developers seem to revel in creating an environment that is as punishing and unforgiving as possible. Rust takes the concept of survival to an extreme level, bordering on sadistic. The constant struggle to gather resources, build a base, and defend it against merciless raiders becomes an exercise in masochism. It quickly becomes apparent that the game is designed to make you suffer at every turn, with no respite in sight.

The gameplay mechanics in Rust are nothing short of a disaster. The lack of any meaningful tutorial or guidance is inexcusable. Players are thrown into a hostile world without any proper introduction, and left to figure out the convoluted mechanics on their own. This steep learning curve is not challenging in a rewarding way, but rather an exercise in frustration and wasted time. Why should players be expected to waste hours of their lives just trying to understand the most basic aspects of the game?

Furthermore, Rust's community is a cesspool of toxicity. The game's open-world PvP nature invites griefers and trolls to run rampant. Instead of fostering a cooperative and enjoyable environment, players are subjected to constant harassment, griefing, and base destruction. It's as if the developers actively encourage the worst aspects of online gaming, providing a breeding ground for toxic behavior that ruins any chance of a pleasant experience.

The optimization in Rust is abysmal. The game demands an exorbitant amount of resources from your computer, leading to constant frame rate drops and lag. Even on high-end systems, Rust fails to deliver a smooth and enjoyable gaming experience. It's a shame that a game with such potential is held back by technical shortcomings that should have been addressed long ago.

In terms of visuals, Rust is a visually unappealing mess. The graphics are outdated and lack any artistic flair or attention to detail. The environment is bleak and dreary, mirroring the overall experience of playing the game. The lack of visual variety further contributes to the monotonous and uninspiring gameplay loop.

Lastly, Rust's development cycle is plagued with a lack of transparency and communication. The developers seem more interested in adding paid cosmetic items and expansions rather than addressing the core issues and concerns of the player base. Promised updates and fixes are often delayed or fail to materialize, leaving players in a perpetual state of frustration and disappointment.

In conclusion, Rust is a prime example of how not to design a video game. Its punishing gameplay mechanics, toxic community, abysmal optimization, lackluster visuals, and questionable development practices make for an infuriating and unrewarding experience. Save yourself the time, money, and aggravation and steer clear of this virtual wasteland.



UPDATE:


After reluctantly investing an additional 20 hours into the relentless abyss that is Rust, I am left with an overwhelming sense of regret and frustration. This survival game masquerades as an engaging experience but fails miserably on multiple fronts, solidifying its position as one of the most infuriating and unenjoyable gaming experiences I have ever endured.

To begin with, the game's learning curve remains as steep as ever, even after dedicating countless hours to it. Rust stubbornly refuses to provide any meaningful guidance or tutorials, leaving players to fend for themselves in a merciless, unforgiving environment. The absence of helpful information or clear objectives forces you to resort to external sources for basic knowledge, rendering the in-game experience frustrating and confusing.

The gameplay mechanics, touted as the game's highlight, quickly reveal their true colors as a convoluted mess. The crafting system is a convoluted nightmare, requiring an excessive amount of time and resources to produce even the most basic items. Progression feels painfully slow, creating an overwhelming sense of grinding and monotony that weighs heavily on any semblance of enjoyment.
[4:03 PM]
Rust's player-versus-player (PvP) aspect, which should add excitement and intensity, instead becomes a cesspool of toxicity and frustration. The game's community is rife with griefers, hackers, and overall toxic behavior. Constantly being raided and losing all your progress due to ruthless, better-equipped players is not only demoralizing but also discourages any attempts at meaningful interaction within the game world.

The technical state of Rust remains subpar, even after countless updates. Frequent crashes, server instability, and a myriad of bugs continue to plague the experience. It's mind-boggling that a game that has been around for so long still suffers from fundamental performance issues.

Moreover, the developers' lack of effective communication and their disregard for player feedback is disheartening. Promised updates and fixes often fail to materialize, leaving the game in a perpetual state of brokenness. It's clear that the developers prioritize profit over player satisfaction, as they continue to release paid DLCs while ignoring the core issues that plague Rust.

In conclusion, my extended time with Rust only served to highlight its myriad of flaws and reinforced my decision to steer clear of this abysmal experience. With its steep learning curve, frustrating mechanics, toxic community, technical shortcomings, and developer indifference, Rust has cemented itself as a prime example of what not to do in a video game. Save yourself the agony and look elsewhere for a worthwhile gaming experience.

Rust, developed by Facepunch Studios, stands as a relentless and unforgiving survival game that thrusts players into a harsh open-world environment where every encounter, decision, and resource matters. Originally released in 2013, Rust has evolved over the years, building a dedicated player base drawn to its challenging gameplay, emergent narratives, and the constant struggle for survival.

The first thing that strikes players in Rust is the ruthless, persistent world they find themselves in. Stripped of clothing and possessions, players must gather resources, build shelter, and contend with the ever-present threats of wildlife and other players. The stark, post-apocalyptic landscapes, ranging from arid deserts to snowy tundras, contribute to the immersive and hostile atmosphere.

Central to Rust's gameplay is the relentless pursuit of resources. Gathering materials like wood, stone, and metal is a constant, time-consuming task that underlines the game's emphasis on survival. The crafting system is intricate, allowing players to create tools, weapons, and structures, fostering a sense of progression as they establish their foothold in the brutal world.

However, what truly sets Rust apart is its intense player interactions. The open-world environment encourages player-versus-player (PvP) encounters, alliances, and betrayals. The prospect of losing everything upon death adds a palpable tension to every interaction, turning encounters into high-stakes negotiations or deadly skirmishes. The emergent narratives that arise from these player-driven interactions create a dynamic and unpredictable gaming experience.

The construction and fortification of bases play a pivotal role in Rust's gameplay. Base design requires careful consideration of layout, security, and resource management, as rival players may attempt to raid and loot your hard-earned possessions. The constant threat of losing everything keeps players on edge, fostering a sense of paranoia that adds to the game's intense atmosphere.

Rust's community-driven development has resulted in regular updates and improvements. New features, optimizations, and quality-of-life enhancements are consistently introduced, reflecting the developers' commitment to refining the game and addressing player feedback. The ongoing evolution of Rust ensures that it remains relevant and engaging for both veterans and newcomers.

While Rust's emphasis on survival and player interaction is its strength, it can also be a source of frustration for some. The steep learning curve, combined with the potential for harsh encounters with more experienced players, may deter newcomers. Additionally, occasional technical issues and bugs, though addressed by the developers, can impact the overall experience.

In conclusion, Rust is an unapologetically challenging and immersive survival experience that thrives on player-driven narratives and emergent gameplay. Its brutal world, intense player interactions, and constant struggle for resources create an experience that is both demanding and rewarding. For those seeking a truly unforgiving survival sandbox with a thriving player-driven ecosystem, Rust stands as a testament to the power of emergent storytelling in the realm of online multiplayer survival games.

Part 1: A Grim Descent into Virtual Chaos: Rust Review

Rust, a so-called "survival" game, is nothing short of a digital wasteland marred by frustration, toxicity, and technical incompetence. This dismal excuse for entertainment masquerades as a game but ultimately delivers an experience akin to a punishing sentence in a virtual purgatory.

First and foremost, Rust's gameplay is an exercise in masochism. From the moment you spawn into its harsh and unforgiving world, you're thrust into a dog-eat-dog environment where survival is less about skill and strategy and more about enduring endless cycles of senseless violence and betrayal. The purportedly dynamic world is nothing more than a glorified playground for griefers and sociopaths, where the only rule is "kill or be killed." Any semblance of enjoyment is quickly crushed under the weight of constant fear and paranoia.

Adding insult to injury is Rust's abysmal community. It's a cesspool of toxicity and hostility, where verbal abuse and harassment are not only tolerated but practically encouraged. Whether you're being mercilessly taunted by a group of power-hungry trolls or subjected to racial slurs and hate speech, the experience is as degrading as it is demoralizing. Any attempt to find camaraderie or cooperation is swiftly met with betrayal and backstabbing, leaving you to question the fundamental decency of humanity.

Technical issues further compound Rust's myriad problems, transforming what could have been a mildly unpleasant experience into a full-blown nightmare. Server instability is the norm rather than the exception, with frequent crashes and disconnects disrupting gameplay at the most inopportune moments. Lag and performance issues plague even the most powerful hardware, turning what should be smooth and fluid gameplay into a stuttering mess.

In summary, Rust is a grim reminder of everything that's wrong with modern gaming. Its brutal gameplay, toxic community, and technical shortcomings combine to create an experience that's as infuriating as it is soul-crushing. Save yourself the anguish and steer clear of this virtual hellscape at all costs.


Part 2: A Lengthy Lamentation: Rust - A Disastrous Descent into Digital Despair

Rust, the survival game that promises a gritty, immersive experience, falls tragically short of its lofty ambitions, plunging players into a maelstrom of frustration, toxicity, and technical inadequacies. This sprawling critique aims to dissect the myriad flaws of Rust, presenting a comprehensive assessment that warrants an unequivocally negative rating.

At its core, Rust is a game defined by its punitive design, masquerading as a test of skill and resilience but ultimately devolving into an exercise in futility. From the moment you spawn into its bleak world, you're thrust into a Darwinian struggle where survival hinges not on wit or strategy, but on your ability to endure relentless onslaughts from griefers and sociopaths. The so-called "sandbox" environment quickly reveals itself as a lawless wasteland, devoid of any semblance of order or fairness. Instead of fostering creativity and exploration, Rust's gameplay is dominated by a cycle of violence and betrayal, leaving players feeling isolated and disillusioned.

The community surrounding Rust serves only to exacerbate its inherent flaws, transforming what could have been a mildly unpleasant experience into a veritable nightmare. Toxicity permeates every aspect of the game, from the incessant barrage of insults and slurs to the blatant cheating and exploitation that runs rampant. Any attempt at cooperation or camaraderie is swiftly met with suspicion and hostility, eroding any hope of meaningful interaction. In this hostile environment, trust is a rare commodity, and alliances are fragile at best, leaving players to navigate a treacherous landscape fraught with danger and deceit.

Technical issues further compound Rust's woes, turning what should have been a tolerable experience into a torturous ordeal. Server instability plagues the game, with frequent crashes and disconnects disrupting gameplay with alarming regularity. Lag and performance issues afflict even the most powerful hardware, transforming what should have been a smooth and seamless experience into a stuttering mess. The game's graphics, while visually appealing at times, come at the cost of optimization, making it inaccessible to all but the most high-end systems.

Rust is a monumental failure on every conceivable level, a cautionary tale of unchecked ambition and egregious oversight. Its punishing gameplay, toxic community, and technical shortcomings combine to create an experience that is as infuriating as it is disheartening. With its myriad flaws laid bare for all to see, it's clear that Rust is a game best avoided, a cautionary tale of the perils of prioritizing innovation over polish and player satisfaction. In the pantheon of gaming disasters, Rust stands as a grim reminder of everything that can go wrong when ambition outstrips ability.

UPDATE After 1300 Hours:  Rust improved somewhat, but it is still filled with very toxic behaviors, most from young boys in the 10-15 range.  Seriously, if your child has this in their steam library and they play frequently, monitor what they are doing. You might be very surprised at the racist and hateful things they might be saying in this game.  Don't believe me, just go watch the YouTube videos on this game. Most will have at least one case of a young child calling someone the N-word or wishing someone's mother had cancer.

UPDATE:  Parents, do not let your children play this game and if they are, delete it ASAP.  Rust is not a game for anyone under the age of 18.  I am not saying this due to the game content itself, but due to the players.  Youtube is filled with videos where kids who cannot be more than 10-14 are spewing out some the the most homophobic, racists, and toxic profanity imaginable.  Get your kids off this game if they play it and if they do not, never let them touch this game.

Rust has the most toxic community in the history of games.  Players will not only kill anything that moves, but take joy in standing over you and insult you with comments about your mother, or laugh at you and say things like "I did not even need to kill you".

This game is a training program for future sociopaths.  It would not surprise me if half the player base pulled the winds off flies and killed small animals as young children.

If your kids play this game and enjoy it, you may want to schedule them for a psychiatric review soon.  If your kids have not yet played this game but want to, don't let them.

My girlfriend broke up with me because I play this game...whatever here is a Hawaii pizza recipe.

Ingredients:

1 pineapple
1 small red onion
1 lb ham (cubed or in chunks)
2 Refrigerated pizza crusts (You can make your own dough but I suggest using premade ones for convience.)
16 oz shredded Mozzarella cheese
6 oz tomato paste 1 can
15 oz crushed tomatoes
1-2 tbsp oregano to taste
2 tbsp Italian seasoning
1/2 tsp garlic powder
1/2 tsp onion powder
1/4 tsp black pepper
1 tsp sugar

Instructions:
1. Preheat oven to 425°F.
2. Simmer tomato paste and crushed tomatoes. Add seasonings and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes or until thick. If you prefer a thinner sauce, take off of the burner sooner.
3. Prepare the ham, onion, and pineapple while the sauce is cooking
4. Put dough on baking sheet with parchment paper or a pizza stone.
5. Spread the pizza sauce on both pizzas.
6. Sprinkle mozzarella cheese on the pizza until it is fully covered.
7. Top the pizza with pineapple, ham and onion.
8. Put the pizzas in the oven and bake for 14-18 minutes or until crust is golden brown.
9. Cut into slices and enjoy the fear from Italians!

I got this game in 2015, I have played on and off for a few years.

You need 2 things:

1: You need a lot of free time to play this game. If you have bills or kids, this might not be for you. This is a game you play for hours at a time.

2: You need friends to play this game. I recommend at least a group of 4 (you and 3 of your friends) to start out with. This game isn't very fun when you play alone.

If you have neither, I do not recommend this game to you.


This game is great when it comes to its highs, and its lows. The grind is mind numbingly boring, but the fire fights are intense. 


There used to be a sense of community, the interactions where you made friends with strangers made a good part of the game. Now theres a lot of kos, which isn't fun. Some of these people have so much time on their hands that they can door camp you for literal real life days. 

There isn't much to do when you reach late game. The time/effort it takes to get there is not worth it, and there is no real reward. Your progress is always wiped in the end.

This is not a game you play casually.  Nor is this an easy game.  You will lose everything with regularity.  You will be killed with even more regularity.  You might be able to get some of your stuff back when you die, depending on the server.  Server wipes happen weekly or monthly, depending on the server.  The wipes are just of your stuff or of your stuff and your blueprints, again depending on the server.  If any of this sounds like it would make you angry, do yourself and everyone else a favor and do not buy or play this game.  
HOWEVER 
if you can get past all of that, it's a really good game.  But it requires a lot of time invested into it.  A LOT of time.

Oh my goodness, let me tell you about Rust! This game is a total blast (literally, because there are guns involved) and it's super addictive. The graphics are incredible and the open-world gameplay is so immersive.

I love that you can build your own base, craft items, and team up with other players to survive in the harsh environment. Plus, there's a bit of a thrill knowing that at any moment, another player could come along and try to steal all your hard-earned loot.

The only downside is that sometimes it can be a bit frustrating when you're killed by other players, but that just adds to the excitement and challenge of the game.

Overall, Rust is a must-play for any gamer who loves survival games and is looking for a new adventure. Trust me, you won't be disappointed!

It's Rust.  It's infuriating, stressful, mind-numbing and mentally and emotionally painful.  Then you pick up a discarded, busted revolver in the middle of a PvP fight and manage one clutch play that makes you invest another 100 hours into it.  You'll question why the entire next 100 hours, then get another clutch play, then reinvest again.  It never ends.  It's Rust.

Garry, why did you make this game?  Why Garry, why?

This game is no ordinary game. This game is an experience crafted by the gods themselves. There is no other platform in which you will simultaneously have the most fun of your life, yet the worst, forcing you to seriously contemplate the possibility of ending your own life due to a 6 year old child. The fact that you can meticulously craft your dream home, only to realize that it is the absolutely easiest base to raid in any players history is just purely delightful. A game where saying the simple word "Hi" could end up with you smashing your own monitor in because a russian dude got offended is an unbeatable experience. Your friends, family, and in general everyone around you will notice a decrease in your mental stability and an increase in hostility to all events around you. And you will stand by it, you wont change a single thing about your life as you start ignoring your friends and loved ones to make sure your base is secured and that no clans of toddlers are raiding you. You will go from hating the game to relying on it. You will start ignoring your dietary needs and will go days without consuming food or water, just to maximize your and efficiency in game. You will slowly start talking less and less in game because you realize that speech is futile, and that the only important thing at the moment is to place a wooden arrow between the eyes of the nazi child in front of you. 
Overall, this game presents you with an unparalleled opportunity to experience life to the fullest extent. If you wish to see gods true wishes from humanity, play this game.

Welcome to RUST, where the only thing rustier than the decaying remnants of civilization is your will to live. This game is a dark comedy of errors, where every step forward feels like two steps back, and the only thing more plentiful than resources is betrayal.

Graphics: If you enjoy the sight of your own impending demise, you'll love the desolate, post-apocalyptic landscapes of RUST. Just make sure to take a moment to appreciate the beautiful sunset before someone shoots you in the back.

Gameplay: It's like playing Russian roulette with a loaded gun and a trigger-happy toddler. Whether you're getting mauled by wildlife, outgunned by other players, or succumbing to hunger and thirst, every death is a slapstick tragedy waiting to happen.

Community: The RUST community is a delightful blend of psychopaths, sociopaths, and occasional masochists. Trust is a rare commodity, and alliances are about as stable as a Jenga tower in an earthquake. But hey, at least everyone's on the same page about being utterly ruthless.

Crafting: Crafting in RUST is like trying to build a sandcastle in quicksand, it's a futile endeavor that's destined to collapse under the weight of your own incompetence. But hey, at least you'll have a good laugh before you die.

Overall: RUST is a twisted carnival of chaos, where every moment is a lesson in humility and every encounter is a potential disaster. It's not for the faint of heart or those with a weak sense of humor, but if you're a glutton for punishment, it's a hell of a good time. Just don't forget to bring your sense of dark humor, you're gonna need it.

The law recognises five types of hate crime on the basis of:

Race
Religion 
Disability
Sexual orientation 
Transgender identity
Any crime can be prosecuted as a hate crime if the offender has either:

demonstrated hostility based on race, religion, disability, sexual orientation or transgender identity
Or

been motivated by hostility based on race, religion, disability, sexual orientation or transgender identity
Someone can be a victim of more than one type of hate crime.

These crimes are covered by legislation (Crime and Disorder Act 1998 and section 66 of the Sentencing Act 2020) which allows prosecutors to apply for an uplift in sentence for those convicted of a hate crime.

The police and the CPS have agreed the following definition for identifying and flagging hate crimes:

"Any criminal offence which is perceived by the victim or any other person, to be motivated by hostility or prejudice, based on a person's disability or perceived disability; race or perceived race; or religion or perceived religion; or sexual orientation or perceived sexual orientation or transgender identity or perceived transgender identity."

There is no legal definition of hostility so we use the everyday understanding of the word which includes ill-will, spite, contempt, prejudice, unfriendliness, antagonism, resentment and dislike.

Rust is a very nice game, Imagine waking up on a deserted island with nothing but a stone and a torch, You'll scavenge for resources, fend off wild animals,

 that intensity is what makes Rust so addictively good. Sure, you might die a few times (okay, maybe more than a few), but each setback just makes your eventual successes feel even sweeter. And let me tell you, nothing beats the rush of raiding an enemy base or teaming up with other players to survive.

Now, I won't lie  Rust can be tough, especially for newcomers. But trust me when I say that the feeling of accomplishment you get from mastering its mechanics is totally worth it. So, if you're up for a challenge and ready to embark on an epic survival journey, do yourself a favor and give Rust a shot. You won't regret it.

Title: Rust: Where "Friendly" Means "I Won't Shoot You... Yet"

Rust, oh Rust. It's like Minecraft's grumpy older brother who's been lifting weights and drinking protein shakes. Developed by Facepunch Studios, this multiplayer survival sandbox is like being thrown into the wild with nothing but a rock and a loincloth, and hoping you can fashion a mansion before someone uses your skull as a doorstop.

First off, let's talk about the graphics. Picture this: you're hiding in a bush, sweating profusely because you just know there's a naked dude with a spear waiting to skewer you for your last can of beans. But hey, at least the trees look nice as they sway in the breeze while you contemplate your life choices.

The player interactions in Rust are a mixed bag of emotions. You'll meet people who are more than happy to give you a helping hand... right up until they decide your hand would look better holding a grenade. It's a bit like playing a game of trust fall, except instead of catching you, your new "friends" catch you off guard and take all your stuff.

Crafting in Rust is like playing MacGyver on steroids. Need a hatchet? Just combine some wood and a rock and voilà, you're ready to chop down trees like a lumberjack with anger management issues. But be prepared to defend your hard work, because every time you build something nice, there's always someone lurking nearby with a torch and a thirst for destruction.

Now, let's address the elephant in the room: the community. Imagine a circus where the clowns are armed to the teeth and the tightrope walkers are juggling landmines. That's Rust in a nutshell. From the guy who serenades you with death threats over voice chat to the one who builds a giant phallic monument outside your base, there's never a dull moment.

In conclusion, Rust is like a rollercoaster ride through a post-apocalyptic carnival. It's chaotic, unpredictable, and guaranteed to leave you questioning your sanity. But hey, if you can survive the madness and make it out with your dignity intact (or at least what's left of it), then you've truly earned your place in the annals of Rust history. Just watch your back, because you never know when someone's going to try to turn it into a dartboard.

Let's be real the fact that I have 7000 hours and are only just now leaving a review must be testament to how all consuming this game is. 

If you are looking to buy this game it is very likely that you have either watched a streamer or a youtuber and thought wow this game looks crazy fun and it is. What most of the videos do not show you is just how unrelenting and brutal this game can be especially when you are new. 

If you are expecting to load in and start killing everyone and getting mad loot then I am here to offer a reality check. There is a tonne to learn in this game and an endless source of fun to be had. But it is a loooooong learning curve.

Tips to help

1. Find a group to learn with or convince a few friends to get it with you. If this is not an option then starting on solo only servers and dead servers 10 pop or less is paramount to learning the game, there is also the PVE server choice but tbh you need to get used to dying early on so I do not recommend. 

2. Wipe day (first thursday of each month or each subsequent thursday)(there is also monday wipes bi weekly wipes and lot's of other options suitable for everyone) is literally the most exciting and most brutal experience anyone can ever endure, especially solo. If you are new I would avoid this like the plague. 

3. There is so much to learn, monuments, tech trees, PVP, PVE bots and puzzles. I highly recommend tackling each of these one by one. each wipe you play build near a new monument, learn it, watch guides get comfortable. once you feel like you own the place then time to get uncomfortable again.

4. Stay off Twitter (X). It may feel like a good source of information but it is mostly just a whining ground for people that have been playing the same game for 10 years and are butt hurt that it has changed. As a seasoned player with over 200 hours sunk into Rust, I can confidently say that this game is a masterpiece of survival and strategy. From the moment you spawn on the unforgiving shores of its procedurally generated world, you're thrust into a relentless struggle for survival, and it's exhilarating.

One of the most captivating aspects of Rust is its realism. Every decision matters, from the resources you gather to the alliances you forge. The constant threat of danger keeps you on your toes, whether from the environment, the wildlife, or other players. And let's not forget about the heart-pounding adrenaline rush of defending your base from raiders or launching a raid of your own.

The game's crafting system is incredibly deep, allowing for endless possibilities in terms of base building, weaponry, and tools. Whether you prefer to fortify your defenses with towering walls and impenetrable fortresses or roam the land as a nomadic hunter-gatherer, Rust accommodates various playstyles with finesse.

But perhaps what keeps me coming back for more is the sense of community that Rust fosters. Sure, there are moments of betrayal and conflict, but there are also moments of camaraderie and teamwork that are truly special. Forming alliances with other players to take down a common enemy or simply surviving together in the harsh wilderness creates bonds that transcend the virtual world.

Moreover, the developers are continually updating and improving the game, adding new features, balancing gameplay, and addressing community feedback. It's clear that they're dedicated to creating the best possible experience for players, and it shows in the quality of the game.

In conclusion, Rust is more than just a game; it's an immersive and addictive survival experience that will keep you coming back for more. With its realistic mechanics, deep crafting system, and dynamic player interactions, it's a game that rewards skill, strategy, and resilience. So if you haven't already delved into its unforgiving world, I highly recommend giving Rust a try. Just be prepared to lose track of time as you embark on your epic journey of survival and conquest—lastly, three words: competitive/scary/complex/random.

Rust is a griefers paradise. There’s nothing quite like finding a guy sleeping in a forest and looting him before he wakes up, or camping outside another player’s fort and killing her when she opens the door. For those who enjoy deadly games of cat and mouse, Rust might just be the best survival game out there. But anybody more interested in building and exploration, or isn’t able to devote themselves to one game, may have a rough time.

Even though other games are better at specific elements like crafting, combat, survival, and exploration, I’ve never played a survival game that combines them quite like Rust. The way it blends survival and competitive genres is fun, especially if you enjoy the goofier bits, like firing rocket launchers at a naked man running from a pig, or being stabbed to death by a person blasting Russian music over their microphone and brandishing a spear. It’s weirder and less polished than the competition, but that’s part of the fun. 

Every time you join a server, your life begins the same way: you wake up on an great-looking island, completely (and graphically) naked, as a randomly generated character based on your Steam ID number. Don’t expect any character customization here; your appearance, race, and gender are all locked. Plenty of survival games go for a grim, faded look, but Rust’s colors pop. The sky is a vibrant blue that I could stare at for hours. The vegetation feels lush and inviting, like it would be fun to wander through the grass barefoot. Buildings are often a nice, rusty red, which lets them pop from the green world around them. The desert and arctic biomes are enjoyable as well, though their environmental hazards mean that they can be difficult to explore without the right gear.

You find yourself here armed with nothing but a rock and a torch. In this respect, Rust doesn’t deviate much from the standard survival formula found in games like Minecraft, The Forest, Stranded Deep, or Subnautica. Using your rock, you chop down trees and gather rocks, which you use to build a rudimentary shelter while keeping an eye on hunger, thirst, and health gauges. Over time, you’ll find blueprints that let you build better tools, which greatly improve your chances of survival.

That progression can feel stunted, because finding blueprints in Rust is unreliable at best. duplicate blueprints for unneeded items are common, while essentials like a hatchet can be elusive. When that happens, you need to research blueprints for items you find in the world. That means finding a research table or building a level-one workbench, and then crafting a research table of your own. All of this requires you to have hundreds of the appropriate materials on hand to craft, and there’s still a degree of chance involved with finding the items you need to deconstruct. That leads to a lot of frustrating grinding.

One of the parts I found most frustrating is that, despite rocks being everywhere in Rust, only certain rocks are usable as the valuable crafting material known as stone, and I frequently ran into stone shortages. Wood is abundant in comparison, despite both materials being necessary for crafting early game items. I often found myself wandering through piles of rocks on the ground hoping they were stone pickups, but was almost constantly disappointed.

Rust’s resource gathering system as a whole is odd and mismatched. Certain items, but not all of them, have markings for where to strike to get the best amount of resources. Chop a tree and a red X will appear. Minerals and metals you can mine shimmer at the right spot. These points move as you strike, which can lead to some awkward shuffling around the resource as you try to maximize your resources. Worse still, player reach isn’t very far, so you can end up whiffing plenty of strikes while chopping down a tree right in front of you.

There’s a kind of zen to wandering around the island, wondering what happened to make it so abandoned. A few times, I encountered a mysterious grey helicopter which patrolled the island until it spotted another player and opened fire on them. I did my best to avoid helicopters after that. Airplanes occasionally fly overhead as well, but they seem to be friendlier, occasionally dropping supply crates. Rust doesn’t have a story like Subnautica does, so it never explains why you’re on this abandoned island or why helicopters are unfriendly and airplanes aren’t. Even The Forest begins with a plane crash.

A lot of the ability to progress is based on the luck of the draw. For instance, much of the best loot is found in radiation zones that require protective gear, so if you’re not lucky enough to find some, you’re going to have a hard time exploring those zones without dying. I’ve spent hours on a map without finding any kind of protection; other times, I was able to enter the zones almost immediately thanks to lucky radiation suit drops.

All of that happens while contending with hostile players, which adds a constant element of danger. There can be over 400 people on a single server, and they’re all potentially dangerous. Like the once-popular zombie survival game DayZ, it’s best to approach other people with a distrustful eye. Cooperation is certainly possible, especially if you go in with friends, but most interactions with strangers seem to result in trash talk and combat. Often, that’s just one player ambushing the other and killing them before they know what hit them.

Most of the text chat I encountered involved players colorfully accusing each other of various perceived injustices, ranging from being inexperienced with Rust’s mechanics to camping outside a base and making it impossible to leave. It was almost entirely aggressive and immature, and I was thankful that Rust included an option to turn it off. And it made me happier that killing them and taking their stuff is such a big part of surviving here.

Unfortunately, the combat never really feels good enough to be exciting on its own merits because of weak-feeling and inaccurate weapons. Don’t expect the terse battles of PUBG or Fortnite here (though some Rust servers do have their own battle royale modes). But the stakes are high: losing a fight with rare gear in your inventory can mean hours of valuable crafting and resource gathering down the drain. That adds a sense of tension.

The problem is, on heavily populated servers I often found myself killed before I had a chance to establish a base or try more peaceful pursuits; competitive Rust is not great if you want to try your hand at being a hemp farmer, unless you’re fortunate enough to find a group of like-minded players. One of the advantages to Rust’s structure is that there are plenty of servers out there; want to focus on crafting? Find a low-population server and you’ll likely be left alone. Only interested in the combat? There are several battle royale servers to pick from.

But the fear of losing everything persists in an unwelcome way even when you’re not playing, because once you start a game, Rust expects you to spend most of your gaming time playing Rust. Your base, for instance, will fall apart if you don’t constantly log in to restock its tool closet. When you’re not contending with other players, you’re busy scrounging for food, water, shelter, and heat just to stay alive. And even success is temporary: if you start on a new server, or your server gets wiped for any reason, you have to start over from scratch. Rust has no real persistence, other than blueprints for cosmetic items that you can receive as random drops on Steam.

If you ever need c4 then here is how to make it. 

The formula for the plastic explosive the US military calls C4 is publicly known. The composition of C4 is:

91% RDX

5.3% dioctyl sebacate or dioctyl adipate

2.1% polyisobutylene rubber

1.6% mineral oil.

All percentages are by weight, so make sure you use a good scale. Too much of the plasticizers and you’ll get a runny, gooey mess. Not enough, and you’ll end up with useless brittle chunks.

Take all the above ingredients, and blend/melt them together in a way that results in a smooth rubbery paste, but make sure whatever method of blending you use doesn’t heat the product up too much, because after all, it IS intended to go boom.

Rust offers an intriguing blend of survival, strategy, and social interaction, making it a standout experience in the gaming landscape. Its unique approach to player-driven narratives and unforgiving survival mechanics creates a challenging yet rewarding environment. As the game evolves toward its beta phase, its potential shines even brighter. Rust is not just a game; it's a test of wit, will, and the ability to forge alliances or rivalries. I'm truly excited to see how it continues to develop. Definitely, a unique experience with high expectations for its future.

You Either Quit a Hero
Or Stay Long Enough to Become a Villian.

Rust, the survival game, is a wild and unforgiving experience. Imagine being naked and alone on a peculiar island, where the grass crunches beneath your feet as you futilely smash your rock against a pine tree. You might have gathered mushrooms and flax to stave off hunger, fashioning a burlap shawl to cover your shame. But then, you hear it—the faint voice of another player in Rust.

This game has a distinctly regressive effect on humanity. As you’re spotted by an idiot, the voice chat merges with the draw distance. The shit-talk quietly tickles your ear, growing louder and more confident as the player approaches. Suddenly, you’re hopping over shotgun shells while absorbing an entire dictionary of insults. No other game indulges our lack of humanity quite like Rust, and it’s both hilariously antagonistic and strangely compelling.

PC Gamer’s verdict: Rust is a malicious experience filled with betrayal, cruelty, and greed. It’s frustrating yet sublime, drawing players into its brutal world of PvP survival. Whether you love it or hate it, Rust leaves an unforgettable mark on those who dare to venture onto its silly island1.

So, if you’re up for a challenge, grab your rock, forge alliances, and prepare for a rollercoaster of emotions in the harsh world of Rust. Just remember: it’s not about the bananas; it’s about survival! 🍌🔥

[h1] All Rust terms [/h1] 
Welcome to my full list of Rust slang/terms, my goal is to educate all new rust players about all the terms you need to know about guns, players, monuments, and much more, with a description.
This will be updated in the future, and I will do a bit every day.
[h2] Players [/h2]
- New Gen 
A player that is new to the game, after the recoil change.
- Old gen
A player that played before the recoil change, or all the way back to legacy rust.
- Naked
A freshly spawned player that is... Naked! equipped with the trusty rock and torch.
- Prim
A player with some hide/burlap clothes, usually equipped with a bow, crossbow, or nail-gun.
- Door-camper
A player that sits outside your front door, usually with a shotgun with the goal to catch you unaware when you leave your base.
- Roof-camper
A player that sits on their base, in their shooting floor or roof, that shoots anyone on sight, usually with the goal of... Nothing. Just clicking fresh-spawn head's, probably just to cool off after losing a kit.
- Hazzy 
A player wearing a hazmat, usually equipped from anything from a crossbow to a Sar or Tommy.
- Tier 2 
A player with Tier 2 equipment, which includes just said Hazzy, equipped with road sign kit with a Sar or Tommy.
- Tier 3
The big boys of Rust, A player with the best kits in the game, wearing metal face-mask and chest-plate, and equipped with an Ak.
- Counters
Player/players that come to your monument/raid with the goal of killing you and stealing your progress!
[h2] Weapons [/h2]
- Ak 
Assault Rifle, The favourite gun among all Rust players! This gun is a force to be reckoned with, be wary if you face one.
- SAR
Semi Automatic Rifle, Another favourite. in the name, its a Semi Automatic, and its a Rifle!
- Tommy
The Thompson, my 2nd favourite SMG in the game!
- SAP 
Semi Automatic Pistol. (not much to say)
- Revy
Revolver (the shitty Tier 1 one)
- Bolty 
Bolt action rifle, The classic playmaker. (200% more coolness without scope)
- L9
The L96, Bolty, but cooler.
- M2
If you hear about ~50 bullets go off at once and they sound scary, RUN.
- Crossy
Crossbow.
- Comp bow
Compound bow.
[h2] Monuments/Special events [/h2]
- Smoil
Small Oil rig, Contains heavily armed scientists and a potential for many riches. Be careful for contesting, this monument is sought out after every other survivor on the island.
- Large 
Large Oil rig, Contains even MORE heavily armed scientists and a guarantee for as much riches as one can desire, but be wary, this monument is even more sought out after, containing big groups usually contesting it. 
- Cargo
This large vessel is only around for a while, and requires a bit of a wait for it to challenge the survivors of the island. This absolute loot filled metal tube contains all the riches your heart can desire, containing usually 3 locked crates, and many Elite and military crates.
- Locked crate
Unlike the ones that naturally spawn on the rigs and cargo, this one will be dropped off at a random monument inland, by a Chinook, containing plenty of loot and PVP! Be prepared!
- Heli
The Attack helicopter! Prepare your cheeks because this ravenous metal dragonfly is hungry for murder. Like the Cargo, it is only around for a while and then leaves, but within that time you have the opportunity to shoot it down! (Its a bit tanky so prepare plenty of medical, ammo, and weaponry to take down this formidable enemy.) The loot can contain the best items you can get, which makes it extremely sought after too, expect alot of PVP if you take it down!
- spermket
Supermarket but you read its sign lol
- Oxums
Oxums gas station
[h2] INSULTS [/h2] 
*inhale* Ah... The art of Rust insults...
- Brick
A player that... struggles with aim.
- Dense
A player that also stuggles with aim.
- Farmbot
A player that farms for a clan/group, but its used as an insult 
- Base-Bitch
A player that is recruited to sit in a clans base, to alert clan members about a raid, manage loot, restock furnaces and do electrical, also used as an insult.
- Roleplayer 
A player that has the goal of just having fun, relaxing and just role playing as a survivor instead of a superhero ak pvp chad with 12k hours.
- Dodging 
Where you avoid a pvp challenge from another player, "because you know your bad :/"

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

"Rust: A Rollercoaster of Emotions"

Oh, Rust, the game where friendships are forged in the fiery crucible of betrayal, where bases are built with the structural integrity of a Jenga tower, and where the sound of footsteps strikes more fear than a horror movie soundtrack. With 1700 hours sunk into this digital wilderness, I've experienced everything from epic battles to embarrassing butt-naked runs through radiation zones.

It's like a virtual reality survival sitcom where you're the star, director, and janitor all at once. Who needs scripted drama when you have a gang of naked players chasing you down with rocks screaming, "Fresh meat!" Or when you spend hours meticulously crafting a base, only to have it raided by a group of raiders who somehow have the architectural skills of an engineer and the patience of a saint.

But behind the laughs lies a tale of heartbreak and loss. Rust isn't just a game; it's an emotional rollercoaster that takes you from the highs of victory to the lows of defeat faster than you can say, "Oh, not again!" Every time you log in, you risk losing everything you've worked so hard for - your loot, your base, and sometimes even your sanity.

The constant threat of being raided or ambushed can wear you down, turning what was once thrilling into a stressful grind. And let's not forget the countless hours spent farming resources, only to have them stolen in the blink of an eye. It's like trying to build a sandcastle while the tide is coming in - futile and heartbreaking.

But despite the tears shed and the countless sleepless nights spent guarding your precious loot, there's something strangely addictive about Rust. Maybe it's the thrill of the chase or the camaraderie forged in the fires of adversity. Or maybe we're all just gluttons for punishment, masochistically drawn to the digital wilderness like moths to a flame.

So, here's to you, Rust, you beautiful, brutal beast of a game. You've brought me joy, frustration, and everything in between. And even though I curse your name more often than not, I wouldn't trade those 1700 hours for anything... except maybe a bigger base and a rocket launcher.

I decided to get the Rust when it went on sale for 50% off. It started out as fun for the first few days but quickly became a chore that you can't leave or you lose all your progress (extremely addicting). To get anywhere in the game you need to play for hours every day. I talked to some other new players like myself and found that they too found that the game was just a cycle of farming nodes, running for comps, getting guns, building the base, rinse and repeat for every wipe. Even PVP and running high-level monuments lost their fun and the most enjoyable thing was just talking to teammates. Some people might enjoy this game but I feel like it is a better decision to either play another game or go out and do something fun. One last thing is that the actual game-play is nothing like what rust you-tubers and is much slower and soul-crushing than you would believe. Hope this helps some people. If you do get the game just be careful about how much you play and make sure you are having fun :)

Can not recommend this game at all. Not friendly to new players, just drops you on the map and gives you no advice about how to begin. Within 1-10 minutes you'll be killed by players already experienced with the game and have to restart. Stones are a valuable resource in the early game and while rocks abound, apparently only special ones can be harvested for resources. If this was an early access game I'd say it had promise, but it's 6 years old now and if this is the state it's in then I cannot recommend it for anyone who's never played it before. Let the current playerbase just stagnate and die, that seems to be what they want anyway.

Additionally, the game itself takes a ridiculously long time to load. Even with a top-of-the-line system with a M.2 SSD, expect it to take 5+ minutes just to load onto a server and start playing.

Rust is truly an amazing, calming and casual game. After a long day at school and work I am always excited to enter the world of rust and use my very vivid imagination to imagine whether my base is still standing or weather it got blown up by terrorists. Rust is an amazing game if you want to sit back on your chair and relax, when running around and satisfyingly breaking barrels to get scrap it truly is an amazing time to listen to some music in the back, It is very relaxing. After a very fun day of grinding rust and having some splended fun. I am always excited to go offline to know whether the amazing base I built from scratch will be to outsmarting from other player to get in. The players in this community are also very friendly! Whenever I need some help or a favor from someone everyone in the server is always very positive and willing to help. The game is also very friendly towards new players. As a new player in rust official you will have a truly amazing time getting enslaved by fellow players with a little over 20 times the hours you have. It really is an amazing game as it has PVP, PVE and slavery. I would highly recommend this game to any player.

This game can be addicting and time consuming so fair warning for those who are casual players. Over the almost 2k hours I have found this game to be the best survival game for the decade. I have played other games like dayz, scum, and many other survival aspect games. This game brings some seriously creative base aspects that are easy to learn and play. the electricity is easy to figure out after maybe one or 2 youtube videos. The monuments are very fun and cant wait to see the updates to come to them. If you are playing this game solo I recommend starting on a solo server where you can only play solo if you are trying to start this game. There are also noob friendly servers for those who wanna practice building and doing monuments with other players. Overall as long as you play the right servers when you are starting you will be eventually ready to go into the real hardcore servers to test you skills. Just always remember this is rust, you cannot trust many people. Have Fun. Ignore the toxic people. Most importantly have fun and play to your liking!

Rust, the game where you learn the true meaning of trust issues. If paranoia and a healthy dose of chaos are your cup of tea, then welcome to the madhouse – also known as Rust.

Picture this: You spawn in, butt-naked, armed with nothing but a rock and the unrealistic hope that you won't be bludgeoned by another equally naked player who's convinced rocks make great fashion accessories.

The game's motto should be: "Rust - where friendships are forged and immediately shattered by a well-placed spear to the back." It's a survival game, but not just against the elements; your biggest threats are the other players who've apparently attended the School of Backstabbing and Ambush Tactics.

And let's not forget the in-game voice chat – a symphony of chaos where you'll hear everything from battle cries to someone serenading you with questionable renditions of '80s power ballads. It's like a dysfunctional family reunion, but with more crossbows.

Yet, despite the madness, Rust is oddly addicting. It's like a toxic relationship you can't quit – you keep coming back for more punishment because, deep down, you know it's the kind of crazy you secretly enjoy.

So, strap on your hazmat suit, brace yourself for a rollercoaster of emotions, and remember: In Rust, if your not paranoid your not playing it right!

TLDR:
The backbone of the survival game industry.  Dont play this if you have problems with anxiety or heart issues.

Title: The Irresistible Allure of Rust: A Passionate Affair with the Game

Introduction:

In the vast landscape of online multiplayer games, there exists a virtual world that has captured the hearts and minds of gamers worldwide — Rust. This survival-based game, known for its unforgiving nature and dynamic player interactions, has woven itself into the fabric of gaming culture. For some, including myself, the mere thought of living without Rust is akin to severing ties with an integral part of their digital existence.

The Inescapable Grip:

Rust, with its harsh landscapes, constant threat of danger, and the never-ending pursuit of resources, has an uncanny ability to captivate its players. The challenge of starting with nothing but a rock and a torch, and gradually building an empire in a world teeming with hostile entities, creates an adrenaline-fueled experience that is impossible to replicate.

The Social Ecosystem:

One of Rust's most enchanting aspects is its social ecosystem. The game compels players to forge alliances, create factions, and engage in diplomacy, creating a dynamic social tapestry that mirrors the complexities of real-life relationships. The bonds formed in Rust often transcend the digital realm, leading to lasting friendships and shared memories that linger long after the game is turned off.

Architectural Ingenuity:

Rust allows players to unleash their architectural creativity in a virtual environment. The satisfaction of constructing elaborate bases, complete with intricate traps and defensive mechanisms, is unparalleled. The game becomes a canvas for architectural expression, pushing players to experiment with designs and collaborate to build structures that withstand both the test of time and the onslaught of rival players.

The Unpredictable Nature of Gameplay:

Rust's unpredictable and ever-evolving gameplay is a constant source of excitement. The thrill of exploration, the adrenaline rush during intense firefights, and the strategic planning required for successful raids contribute to an immersive experience that keeps players coming back for more. The lack of a predetermined narrative allows each session to unfold in a unique and unpredictable manner, ensuring that no two experiences are alike.

Community and Camaraderie:

Rust's community is a diverse and vibrant mix of players from around the globe. The shared experiences, whether through triumphs or defeats, create a sense of camaraderie among players. Whether one is participating in large-scale server-wide events or simply engaging in casual banter, Rust's community fosters a unique sense of belonging that adds immeasurable value to the overall gaming experience.

Conclusion:

In the realm of online gaming, Rust stands as a testament to the power of immersive gameplay, social interaction, and creative expression. The game's ability to weave together elements of survival, strategy, and camaraderie has created an environment that is not just a digital escape but a living, breathing world where players can forge memories that endure beyond the confines of the screen. For those who have tasted the allure of Rust, the prospect of living without it is unfathomable, as the game has become an integral part of their gaming identity.

Feb 28, 2017: Rust is quite a dangerous survival game. Players are the folk to watch out for. Hard to trust someone that isn't on your friendlist. I've had a few betrayels & traitorous acts against me, all caught me by surprise. 
The game's fun, still constantly being updated. The updates obviously enforce 'wipes' that make servers have to start fresh, which is disappointing, but it's also for the best considering folk could become rather overpowered towards new players.
Things can get repetitive each wipe, but at least it gives you new things to try & new places to explore each random map generation. 

TL:DR; The game is quite fun & I do recommend it, gets slightly repetitive but it is worth the price.

Edit: Feb 1, 2024: The game has grown stale & repetitive. Player Character Model (Gender/Race) cannot be customized & you are stuck with what you are given, permanently. Facepunch could have at-least made it randomized. As for the rest of the game; It focuses more on PvP than it does anything else now. The graphics are dated, the recent updates do not focus on adding more to the game; especially outside of PvP, & worst of all, the game uses way too much RAM, & the dedicated server setup is janky garbage compared to Garry's Mod's. 
I hear rumors of Rust 2, so here's to hoping that they either turn Rust around or make a better Rust experience in their new game. Given how the game is practically PvP oriented & nothing is designed for anything but repetitive gameplay (especially with the wipes each month due to poor balancing in gameplay), I honestly suggest getting the game when it is on-sale, not for the asking price of $40.00 USD. Game's just a predictable PvP hunger games mess. Community/Modded servers are the way to go, & trying to set one up can be somewhat frustrating when you can't even tell if your vanilla server is functioning or not. And the RAM, why every asset has to immediately be loaded is beyond me. 32Gb of RAM, & I can't host the game & server at the same time without killing the server's performance by capping out the RAM. I expected better from Facepunch on the server-side of things. Honestly, this changes my review from positive to negative.

Edit Feb 2, 2024: Turns out on the same day I updated my review to negative, Facepunch Studios has added backpacks to the game (a feature that already existed as a third-party modification beforehand), addressed textures, mipmaps, compression, ram, shader, & optimization issues, & improved the game slightly. Still, will be leaving the review as negative until player model is at the very least, randomized upon in-game deaths. But great work on everything else. Hope to see more performance improvements.

I have almost the same hours of this on ark, which is actually insane to me as I have 5.6k+ on both, but this is my favorite game of all time. If you are a grown man with a full time job, this game is not for you (unless you don't like working) If you're a college student, and you touch this game, you're failing. This game is time consuming, life ruining, wife stealing chaos. You will stay up endless nights waiting for an offline raid to protect the loot you worked so hard for. When you finally fall asleep, the raiders strike and offline you without a chance to defend. Days of your time could be gone, all your progress gone  like nothing ever happened. Then you start again, and the same cycle repeats. Theres a bunch of racist children and grown men from Russia, China, chorea, every country possible, who will spam the n word more then a scrawny white kid on call of duty. Then theres the 20-30 man zergs who get pressed when you kill them and foundation wipe your base, then call you slurs and trash :/. Then theres the hundreds of grubs with double barrels who will blow your head off whenever they get the chance to, and take all the stuff you just got. And then its the grown men who say they're unemployed and they got all day and night to offline you (which rarley happens because they're bluffing) Overall, if you can tolerate all the downsides of this game, then you will 100% dedicate months and years of your life playing it.
