One can spend more time in their base/house/compound/castle/storefront/hanger/dock/fishing hut/farm than they do out in the world. One can get eaten by bears or wolves while gathering resources, or one can eat cooked bear and wolf meat, while sitting by a campfire, crafting one's new wolf skull head dress, leather gloves,   cape, and pants from the hide of said wolf or bear. 

One can also find a fix up a car, or horse, or helicopter, or tugboat, or submarine and go cruising around the map, looking for other players to get fresh donations from, or locations to loot. 

This game can be played in many different ways, i highly recommend.

This game saved my life.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

i wrote a review

Baked Alaska
Baked Alaska is a cake topped with ice cream and caramelized meringue. It's so delicious and a great way to wow your guests! You can use your favorite flavor of ice cream or a combination of flavors.

Prep Time: 25 mins
Cook Time: 10 mins
Additional Time: 10 hrs
Total Time: 10 hrs 35 mins
Ingredients
2 quarts vanilla ice cream, softened, or as needed

8 egg whites

⅛ teaspoon cream of tartar

⅛ teaspoon salt

1 cup white sugar

1 8-inch round prepared white cake layer

Directions
Gather all ingredients.

Line the bottom and sides of an 8-inch round mixing bowl with plastic wrap. Pack softened ice cream into the prepared bowl, then flatten the top and cover with more plastic wrap. Freeze until firm, 8 hours to overnight.

Beat egg whites, sugar, cream of tartar, and salt in a mixing bowl until stiff peaks form.

Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and place cake in the center. Remove ice cream from the freezer, discard plastic wrap, and turn ice cream out on top of cake.

Quickly spread meringue over ice cream and cake, swirling in decorative patterns if desired. Freeze for 2 hours.

Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Bake cake on the lowest oven shelf until meringue is light brown, 8 to 10 minutes.

Slice and enjoy!

I LOVE THIS GAME

For me it was like the perfect mix of a slower paste gathering game such as minecraft with an intense pvp aspect that you get with quick battle royal games. The reason I liked this mix so much was because I loved the slower parts of games that allow you to work towards something while also enjoying the thrill of fighting other players as well. Unlike most games, rust's combination of the two made the pvp so much more intense than almost any other game i had played. This was because I had so much to lose if i lost a battle. This weight of every scenario got me addicted but it was an experience that I soon became addicted to which pushed me to get better an better at the game so I would lose less. This loop of playing is something I do not regret and recommend for someone that's tired of the repetitive constant action of highly competitive fps games but also doesn't want to just play a game that is terrible slow and not as rewarding.

Good Yes

The full-time job you pay for.  The only thing keeping Rust from WoW levels of lotus-eating is that the game wipes periodically.  It's genuinely disturbing to me that the game's design is so unhealthy that they built a mechanism to alert you IRL when something bad happens in-game, and that if you don't respond, you lose all your progress.

Maybe there [i]are[/i] servers out there that are only online for certain hours each day, certain days of the week, to help curb the incentives of no-life-ing this game.  I can't find them.  And thus, this game forces you down one of the following paths:

-become a 24-hour on call gamer
-accept the risk of losing everything whenever you engage in [i]any activity that is not Rust[/i]
-play a 5x/10x server, where accomplishments don't feel meaningful because progression is compressed and accelerated, and bases are hideously bloated because everyone is rich enough to afford the mass honeycombs (and if you're not doing it too then you're at a disadvantage)

Here's a mini coffee cake recipe:

**Mini Coffee Cake**

**Ingredients:**

**For the Streusel Topping:**
- 1/4 cup all-purpose flour
- 2 tablespoons brown sugar
- 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
- 2 tablespoons unsalted butter, cold and diced

**For the Cake:**
- 1 cup all-purpose flour
- 1/2 teaspoon baking powder
- 1/4 teaspoon baking soda
- 1/4 teaspoon salt
- 2 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened
- 1/3 cup granulated sugar
- 1 large egg
- 1/2 cup plain yogurt or sour cream
- 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract

**Instructions:**

1. Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C). Grease and flour a mini cake pan or line it with parchment paper.

2. **Streusel Topping:**
   - In a small bowl, combine the flour, brown sugar, and cinnamon for the streusel.
   - Add the cold, diced butter and use your fingers to mix until it resembles coarse crumbs. Set aside.

3. **Cake Batter:**
   - In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

   - In a separate larger bowl, cream together the softened butter and granulated sugar until light and fluffy.

   - Add the egg to the butter-sugar mixture and beat well. Stir in the yogurt (or sour cream) and vanilla extract.

   - Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing until just combined.

4. **Assembling:**
   - Pour half of the cake batter into the prepared mini cake pan.

   - Sprinkle half of the streusel topping over the batter.

   - Add the remaining batter and top it with the rest of the streusel.

5. **Baking:**
   - Bake in the preheated oven for 20-25 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.

6. **Cooling:**
   - Allow the mini coffee cake to cool in the pan for a few minutes before transferring it to a wire rack to cool completely.

7. **Serve:**
   - Once cooled, slice and serve. Enjoy your delicious mini coffee cake!

This recipe is designed for a small batch, making it perfect for individual servings or sharing a cozy treat with someone special.

The game is hollow garbage. It looks nice, the weapons play nice and whatever is actually there to explore and do is really good. But that's it. That's the game. You spawn in, die to an animal or armed player, respawn and then grind for an hour or two to get resources. You'll then upgrade weapons and explore points of interest, if you don't die to a clan that is (bonus points if you get shot by a base turret that is left out to snipe people even when they're offline). I'd say it takes around 4-5 hours to get a waterpipe shotgun if you are lucky and do not die.

You also of course want to make a base to set your spawn and protect your loot. Simple, right? Well, you play mining simulator until you get the materials to make one. Every base has a tool cabinet, that is required for the base to exist. You have to consistently upkeep your base with materials. If you so much as take a day off or two your base will decay. That's if it doesn't get raided by a clan.

Limited squad servers are a little better I guess. But everyone in the game is a tryhard who has the progression system completely ingrained in their head. No one even talks to each other either anymore like you see in popular videos. That is of course except for slurs and then being called more of them upon being downed. The game is still a huge grind and it feels more like work than a videogame.

So obviously you try out a server that multiplies the amount of materials and loot you get. Awesome, I have gear now and I don't have to worry about 12 hours minimum of grinding to get back to this progression level! And then you fight people. That's it, you fight people. The places to explore you will see quite a bit, and they get repetitive fast. The survival mechanics are just kind of annoying. Wow, you get cold if in cold place, you have to eat sometimes and then sometimes you have to run from the 3-4 animals that actually exist trying to kill you.

There's nothing wrong with fighting. But the game is way too much of a grind for how little good pvp you get from it. Why shouldn't I just play Counter Strike 2 or Call of Duty? 

I bought it when it was 20$ and I wish I could get my money back. So if anyone wants to call me bad at the game and then give me clown awards please do so. Any amount of points I would get is at least something I actually got out of the game.

Update: as of 1/29/2024 the cheating has become a defacto part of the game. The Rust cycle works like this: an impressionable kid sees Rust on Twitch and buys the game. These new players go down one of these paths that make revenue for F*c*Punch: A) Quits playing because it wasn't what they expected, but plays too long to get a refund. B) Gets frustrated playing official and moves to a snowflake server and lives happily ever after, never having actually played Rust. C) Has their little feelings hurt because they are legends in their own minds and have to prove it to the underpants gnomes so they buy a cheat client and haunt the vanilla servers that don't have any real penalty in place for cheating. D) Go to one of the privately run modded servers that are almost as bad as the cheater filled vanilla servers since the top players congregate on them and proceed to play the most sweaty Rust imaginable -- getting owned by sweaty 24/7 clans and cheaters is ultimately the same thing at the end of the day. E) Become streamers themselves and pretend like Rust is a great game without issues to  help swindle the next generation of Rust players.
------------
Update: as of 4/7/2022 the cheating has made the game unplayable unless you play on some goofy modded or private server. The only purpose this game has now is if you want to stream it to entertain others. And apparently this is the primary revenue driver for Facepunch, as it pulls in toxic children who further spoil the game for the old-school honest players. Time to find an alternative.
------------
Update: as of 6/9/2021 the cheating has become substantially worse.
------------
Rust has become plagued with cheat-client clans. Hacking tools were always a problem, but they've become so ultra-organized that you will only last a few days on the official Facepunch servers (these are the servers that Facepunch runs). The problem is so out-of-control that even on the first day of wipe, these servers have less than 50% of server capacity these days -- where they used to be queued up at over 100% capacity. People have been literally abandoning their bases and declaring in global that they were hack-raided or aimbotted for the last time, and that they're quitting.
But even the  third party commercially operated official-certified servers that supposedly maintain full-time admins such as Rustified, can barely control this problem with what amounts to sketchy admin staff. Regardless, these servers are overcrowded on wipe day and charge a fee to get in front of the queue -- a flimsy business model that doesn't appear to raise enough revenue to even pay their admins, so you can imagine what you get for free in the way of reliable admins. Unfortunately, the users of these cheat-clients have become masters at hiding their tracks, so even the rare good admin often boils down their decisions on subjective player reporting.
I rest the blame squarely on Facepunch, as they have done virtually nothing about this issue from day one.  Their token effort anti-cheat software, provided by a third party, is thin and glitchy -- barely effective only on the most egregious cheats -- and hilariously kicks people for fly hacking when they are, for example, stuck on a ladder or falling from a chopper. And even when it actually detects a real fly hack in progress, there is no follow up after the kick. No audit of any kind. The person *MUST* be reported for there to be any follow up, and often reports are ignored unless you are lucky enough for there to be an admin  logged in that isn't too stoned to use a keyboard.
It's interesting to point out, however, what their anti-cheat strategy has been over the past few years: rather than doing a deep-analysis of the problem and coming up with an effective response, they have opted for simply banning offenders in mass. As I mention above, this takes an act of congress, but once they have the 50 gigabytes of log data and 4000 reports, it can happen. However, It is common knowledge among experienced rust players that the banned individuals simply buy another copy of Rust. And in the case of the commercially operated server, also another VIP slot. Odd how this cycle just seems to be generating more revenue and not preventing cheats. What do you think?

Starting to play in the late autumn evening, relaxing and pouring myself some aromatic coffee, within 2 hours I had a reaction, just like the strongest reaction. They simply didn’t let me get out of the beach. Having a stone in one hand, and a causal place in the other hand, you find yourself up against fully Armed people sitting on the towers. Many holo-asses despaired and killed each other right on the spot where they spawned, some turned out to be very successful in this, and soon a whole tribe of such seasoned holo-asses was formed under my leadership. We made spears and killed
freshly woken up, stocking up on human flesh, and of course thinking through a plan to escape from the beach.
There was a semicircle of walls and towers around the beach within a radius of 500 meters, but since the owners were several people, there were holes in the intersection of their zones of influence. On the section of the wall we chose, there were usually 3 people standing with bolts, enjoying a kind of tavern defense. After making a couple of test runs, we discovered that only two were shooting at night, and the third was stabbing in the eyes in the dark, this would later play into our hands. One person out of five even got behind the walls on the third try, but found there a minefield of traps and mines themselves.
On the third night we were ready, in our reserve there were 10 people with spears and 5 bare-asses. The Golozhops were recruited under pain of multiple deaths and were our rearguard (cannon fodder). Having moved out from the beach in a dispersed order, under a barrage of two chatter, only 3 naked-ass and 7 spearmen reached the walls. We were faced with the task of quickly overcoming the minefield, then we lined up in single file, sending the remaining bare-asses forward. They were enough for exactly one hundred meters, then we took the risk ourselves. The supplies of human flesh helped a lot; everyone had 3 stacks. Having reached halfway, we heard people start shooting at us from behind, so we started running into the scattered rest of the way. Mines began to explode all around and traps began to click, people fell one by one.
Only two people reached the forest, which was the border of the minefield - me and another spearman. Finally we were free. My companion cursed loudly and went home. I was left alone, wow, this is how the game started on the server. Now I had to build a house.

[h1]2024 edit: [/h1]
A good game ruined by a toxic community, and some bad raiding mechanics.

Show your pvp and planning skills to build and get your loot trough hard work, only for people with no IRL life to stare at their monitors 24/7 and wait until you logoff to go sleep/work and then raid you with no effort and little risk at 4AM.

Offline raiding is one of the banes of this game, and in literal years of this game being out, the devs have done literally nothing to discourage offline raiding and encourage online. 

Also the last few years they have been introducing more and more [b]P2W Pay-To-Win[/b] mechanics. Its started small really, with items that make little difference such as better base organisation, but it keeps pushing in that direction. Also custom servers are 99% of them pay-to-win with "Kits" and "Subscriptions" which give paying players humongous advantages. 

The rest of my review still stands:

[h1]Pros: [/h1] 
- Interesting mechanics
- Addictive Gameplay (Could be considered a con)
- Large mod community for various kinds of players
- Really fun with a few friends
[h1]Cons: [/h1] 
- Some mechanics actively encourage griefing and toxic behaviour.
- There is little to no effort by the devs to encourage positive/friendly behaviour. 
- Made for people with a lot of time, not skill or wits. (The players who play a few hours a week are devoured and toyed with by the players who play half a day every day)
- Quite shit as solo, no servers are properly made/balanced for solo play

Its almost a good game, but it is quite clear the devs prioritize making stuff that will enslave players to play longer, rather than make the game a bit more balanced and friendly. This is game that literally makes money by encouraging players to grief each other. I would be ashamed of myself if I was working as a developer or game designer in this

The game is very good, excluding the community. I highly recommend it for people who just want to play on PVE or Roleplay servers, and for those that want a game that respect their time, play 5x or 10x servers. The community is incredibly toxic on most official servers, which are PVP. If you plan on playing PVP, keep this in mind, or mute voice and text chat entirely. Playing in a group is always more fun, but isn't a "must" unless youre on those sweaty official servers. I think the recent price increase to $40 on top of needless dlc (specifically the building skins/lumberjack outfits), is kind of shitty, but it's still worth it on sale. Keep in mind, I bought this game in 2015, and played legacy for a long time before I ever touched the current version, and I also only paid $10. Even for $40, my 1700 hours or so would be worth it.

Edit 1/28/2024: I forgot to mention you need crazy high specs to run this game, specifically RAM. If you have anything less than 32 GB of RAM, plan on sticking to the tiniest maps otherwise your shit will be fucked. (My RAM usage runs up to 16GB while in-game at idle.)

Rust is a game all about Survival. You spawn along the side of a beach and all you get to start out is your naked self, a rock, and a torch. (Your get a random Skin Colour and Sex)

There is a second approach to Rust, where instead of being an Overprotective Little Piece of Sh*t, you can interact with one another.

Rust: A Savage Symphony of Survival and Triumph


Rust, the magnum opus of Facepunch Studios, is an unforgiving, unapologetic masterpiece that beckons players into a world where every sunrise is a testament to survival and every structure built stands as a monument to tenacity. If you're seeking an immersive and gripping survival experience that transcends the mundane, Rust is the definitive title that will leave you craving for more.

Visual Mastery:
From the moment you spawn on the desolate beach, the visual allure of Rust is undeniable. The game's landscapes, meticulously crafted with stunning detail, evoke a sense of desolation and grandeur simultaneously. The stark contrast between the lush greenery and the dilapidated structures creates an atmosphere that is as haunting as it is beautiful.

Raw Realism:
Rust's commitment to realism is a double-edged sword, cutting through the veneer of traditional survival games. The need for sustenance, the brutal impact of environmental elements, and the ever-looming threat from fellow players create a visceral experience that immerses you in the raw essence of survival. Every decision, from resource gathering to building your shelter, carries weight and consequence.

Dynamic Player Interaction:
The brilliance of Rust lies in its dynamic player interaction. The open-world PvPvE environment ensures that every encounter with another player is an unpredictable dance of alliances and betrayals. The emergent gameplay, shaped by player-driven narratives, adds layers of depth and excitement to Rust that few games can match. Your journey is not solely defined by your survival instincts but by the alliances you form and the rivalries you kindle.

Masterful Crafting and Base Building:
Crafting in Rust is an art form, a delicate dance of resource management and strategic planning. The vast array of items, structures, and weapons at your disposal allows for unparalleled customization. Building your base becomes a personal odyssey, a statement of resilience against the relentless threats that lurk in the shadows. The sense of accomplishment when your fortress stands tall is unparalleled.

Endless Replayability:
Rust's dynamic ecosystems and ever-evolving player interactions contribute to its endless replayability. No two sessions are alike; each wipe brings a fresh start and a new narrative to unfold. The game's constant updates and additions keep the experience dynamic, ensuring that Rust remains a vibrant and evolving canvas for survival enthusiasts.

Community and Social Dynamics:
The multiplayer aspect of Rust is not just a feature; it's a social experiment. The alliances forged, the rivalries kindled, and the emergent player-driven narratives create a sense of community that extends beyond the digital realm. Joining a server is not just a game session; it's an opportunity to participate in a living, breathing world shaped by the collective actions of its inhabitants.

In conclusion, Rust is not just a game; it's an experience that transcends traditional gaming boundaries. Its raw realism, dynamic player interactions, and relentless survival challenges make it a must-have for anyone seeking an immersive and gripping experience. If you're ready to step into a world where every decision matters, alliances are fleeting, and triumph is hard-earned, Rust is the definitive title that will leave you yearning for the next sunrise in this savage symphony of survival. Face the challenge, build your legacy, and embrace the chaos of Rust.

This game is complete aids. Playing it made me lose my sanity within a few months. I highly recommend getting this game, mainly if you have a group to play with. It is very fun if you play casually, or if you play very seriously. Building a base and looting monuments is very fun, and the PvP in the game is great too. It's hard to learn, but still fun regardless.

The previous review is from April of 2021, and it is now January of 2024. Since then, there have been countless changes to the game, from new locations to loot to new ways to play the game. Some things include submarines, tugboats, new monuments, and more. My only complaint is that the combat update was a bit much, however Facepunch is planning many huge updates for 2024. Overall, the game is still great and I recommend it to anyone who likes difficult survival games.
This game will cause offline anxiety and irregular sleeping patterns. But totally worth it.

Despite being sold for a high price just like any other OS version, the Mac version of Rust has been virtually UNPLAYABLE for quite some time now, due to a Unity engine bug that the developers, as part of their disastrous attitude towards customers, have NOT fixed until now. 

To be clear, this has NOTHING to do with the usual childish jokes about Macs not being good for games, etc. - no: I am talking here about abysmal performances of 1-5 fps EVEN with the most powerful Macs and GPUs, normally after just a few minutes of playing at 60fps or more, and regardless of the game being set in the "Potato" or "Ultra" modes.

So if you have a Mac, DO NOT buy Rust - and if you still purchase it, do not forget to write to the devs and ask for a fix to this ridiculous bug.

Its a really fun game in a lot of ways, but there are many things that plague this game. It is not friendly to solo players as there are many big clans with ego issues that will stomp on everyone, and it is also generally just a game that is full of deception and messed up actions between players, which I guess is just kind of in it's nature. The last thing that bothers me is how poorly the game performs. Struggling to pull 90 frames with low graphic settings and decent hardware is very frustrating. I attribute most of this (likely) to the fact that it is a Unity game, which; being written in C#, is not an optimal way to write a game with this many interactions and little things going on with many players.

Me when Rust is an iron oxide, a usually reddish-brown oxide formed by the reaction of iron and oxygen in the catalytic presence of water or air moisture. Rust consists of hydrous iron(III) oxides (Fe2O3·nH2O) and iron(III) oxide-hydroxide (FeO(OH), Fe(OH)3), and is typically associated with the corrosion of refined iron.

Given sufficient time, any iron mass, in the presence of water and oxygen, could eventually convert entirely to rust. Surface rust is commonly flaky and friable, and provides no passivational protection to the underlying iron, unlike the formation of patina on copper surfaces. Rusting is the common term for corrosion of elemental iron and its alloys such as steel. Many other metals undergo similar corrosion, but the resulting oxides are not commonly called "rust".

Keďže mi tento profil nepríde zaujímavý, prikladám recept na Banány v Čokoláde :

Ingrediencie:
4 stredne zrelé banány
200 g čokolády (mliečna alebo horká)
2 polievkové lyžice masla
1 čajová lyžička vanilkového extraktu
Poleva (kokosová strúhanka, orechy, sušené ovocie - podľa chuti)
Postup:
Banány olopte, rozkrojte na polovičky.

Rozpustite čokoládu s maslom vo vodnom kúpeli, pridajte vanilkový extrakt.

Banány namáčajte do čokolády, položte na pečiaci papier.

O polevu pridajte kokos, orechy alebo sušené ovocie (voliteľné).

Nechajte stuhnúť, ideálne v chladničke.

Podávajte a užívajte si sladký zážitok!

Tento recept ponúka skvelú kombináciu sladkých banánov a lahodnej čokolády. Dobrú chuť!
